projectMenu.tabHowToCreate: How to create your own solution
projectMenu.intentionDescription: Etienne integrates traditional IT backend services (like CRON jobs) with coding agents like Anthropic Claude Code or OpenAI Codex. It can be run on the local machine for development and inside a docker container for production.
projectMenu.intentionBullet2: adds a event bus (ZeroMQ) and a condition monitoring system
projectMenu.intentionBullet3: can create public websites exposed under /web
projectMenu.intentionBullet5: showcases service management for additional local services (e.g. vector store, RDF store)
projectMenu.intentionBullet6: demonstrates how to seamlessly integrate agent skills and MCP tools into business processes
projectMenu.intentionBullet7: provides a file system explorer and file type dependent previewers (e.g. mindmaps)
projectMenu.howToCreateParagraph1: Etienne was built with Claude Code 2.0 and the Anthropic 4.5 Sonnet model following a spec-driven approach.
projectMenu.howToCreateParagraph2: If you want to build your own solution, this is the suggested workflow:
projectMenu.howToCreateStep1: place a new requirements specification in the root as markdown file
projectMenu.howToCreateStep2: ask Claude code to implement it
projectMenu.howToCreateStep3: review and refine the results presented by Claude
projectMenu.howToCreateStep4: move the specification to the directory 'requirement-docs'
projectMenu.howToCreateNote: With spec-driven coding the specification is the most important artifact. You can recreate a more sophisticated implementations later on using more capable AI models. In modern DevOps environments IaC is a common approach - with application development the specifications will have the same importance as Terraform scripts nowadays for IaC.
projectMenu.trackAICosts: Track AI inference costs for this project
projectMenu.noScrapbooks: No scrapbooks yet. Create one to get started.
onboarding.step1Explanation:
Hello my name is Etienne.
I am a general AI assistant based on the Anthropic Agent SDK. I can help you when working with files and complex data. You need to copy data into our workspace, so I am able to see them.
onboarding.step2Explanation: I am smart but small - I need a capable AI model to carry me on my missions.
onboarding.step3Explanation:
Great, we're connected!
    I can use several **local services** which store their data in our workspace. So I can remember things and structure complex problems.
onboarding.step4Explanation: I organize all my work in separate project directories. This allows me to stay focused and optimize my memory to one task at hand. We can have several sessions in one project.
onboarding.serviceKnowledgeGraphDesc: A RDF store to hold semantic relations between data objects
onboarding.serviceVectorStoreDesc: A fulltext index using embeddings to find similar data
onboarding.serviceA2ARegistryDesc: Contains two external agents and a list for discovery
onboarding.serviceWebServerDesc: Allows Etienne to create and expose API endpoints. The server is capable of hot-reloading.
onboarding.workspacePathHint: Etienne has access to this directory only.
onboarding.apiKeyHint: You can create an account on
onboarding.projectNameHint: This is a directory inside the workspace folder. Only numbers, lower-case characters and - are allowed.
onboarding.serviceFailedToStart: Service failed to start - port {{port}} not responding after 120 seconds
onboarding.someServicesFailed: Some services failed to start. You can continue anyway or try again.

wizard.benefitTitleStep1: Give your project a unique identity
wizard.benefitDescStep1: A clear project name helps you organize your work and quickly find what you need. Choose a name that reflects the project's purpose.
wizard.benefitDescStep2: The mission brief guides your AI assistant's behavior. A detailed description ensures better, more focused results aligned with your objectives.
wizard.benefitDescStep3: Select a predefined role that matches your project's needs, or create a custom role definition. The agent role determines the assistant's personality, knowledge focus, and working style.
wizard.benefitDescStep4: Skills are pre-built behaviors that enhance your AI assistant. Standard skills are included automatically. Add optional skills to extend functionality.
wizard.benefitDescStep5: MCP tools let your AI assistant interact with external systems and APIs. Add pre-approved tools from the registry or connect to custom servers.
wizard.benefitDescStep6: External A2A agents bring specialized expertise to your project. Select agents that complement your project's goals for enhanced capabilities.
wizard.benefitDescStep7: Start with a familiar look by copying UI settings from an existing project, or begin fresh with the default configuration.
wizard.projectNameHelperText: Only lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens (max 30 characters)

rulesTab.createFirstRuleHint: Create your first rule to start monitoring conditions

actionsTab.manageActions: Manage reusable action templates for your rule actions
actionsTab.createFirstActionHint: Create reusable action templates to use in your rules
examplesTab.simpleDescription: Use simple conditions for exact matching of event properties. Perfect for straightforward triggers like "when a Python file is created" or "when a specific MQTT topic receives a message".
examplesTab.simpleAlert: Simple conditions support wildcard matching with * in string values
examplesTab.semanticDescription: Use semantic conditions for AI-powered similarity matching. Great for finding related content or detecting semantically similar events even when exact wording differs.
examplesTab.semanticAlert: Semantic matching uses vector embeddings with a default threshold of 0.86
examplesTab.compoundDescription: Use compound conditions to combine multiple conditions with logical operators (AND, OR, NOT). Ideal for complex scenarios requiring multiple criteria.
examplesTab.compoundExample: Example: Monitor test file changes AND config changes
examplesTab.compoundAlert: Compound conditions support AND, OR, and NOT operators with optional time windows (in milliseconds)
examplesTab.temporalDescription: Use temporal constraints to filter events by time of day or day of week. Perfect for business hours monitoring or scheduled maintenance windows.
examplesTab.temporalExample: Example: Monitor during business hours only
examplesTab.temporalAlert: Day of week: 0=Sunday, 1=Monday, ..., 6=Saturday. Times use 24-hour format (HH:MM)
webHooksTab.description: POST data/files to this project from external systems. In the base version the endpoint is open, adding header authentication is recommended.
webHooksTab.dedicatedEndpointDesc: POST any JSON payload directly - it will be automatically wrapped as a Webhook event:
webHooksTab.generalEndpointDesc: POST a structured event with explicit group and name:
webHooksTab.promptContextDesc: When a Webhook event triggers a rule, the full JSON payload is prepended to your action prompt:
webHooksTab.multipartFormDataDesc: Upload files along with JSON metadata using multipart/form-data:
webHooksTab.fileStorageDesc: Uploaded files are saved to the project's webhook/ directory, overwriting any existing files with the same name:
webHooksTab.resultingPayloadDesc: The event payload combines your JSON description with file metadata:
webHooksTab.matchFilesAlert: Match files using payload.fileCount:2 or check for specific files in your prompt
